div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: LORD CROMERS REPORT AND HOME PRESS.
div.p: Lord Cromer's report for 1906 has been received with much satisfaction at home, and the Press' joins in a unanimous chorus of praise of his clear and statesman like pronouncement on the administration of Egypt, and the im­portant questions affecting the country which are at present prominent in the public mind. We append a few excorpts :

' Times'': Lord Cromer's annual report upon the condition of Egypt is always singularly instructive, but, owing to various incedents during the course of the last twelvemonth, the report for 1906, which has just been issued by the Foreign Office, deserves more than usual attention, and no part of it will be read with more interest, or may be studied with more profit, than the portion-dealing with the so- called "Nationalist" movement, which we publish this morning in full. A good deal of sympathy has been expressed with the move­ment in this county, not always wisely or according to knowledge. Lord Cromer's observ­ations will, of course, have no weight with the idealists, who bless with undiscriminating approval all agitations in all countries which adopt that eminently deceptive label or with the confident politicians who are satisfied that in a brief vacation tour they can see to the heart of problems which statesmen who have pondered them for life confess that they can not fathom. But with the mass of sensible men, who place their trust in expert knowledge in politics as in other matters, the views of so accomplished an expert cannot fail to have authority. They will remember what Lord Cromer has done for Egypt, and they will appraise his judgment In the light of his achievement-. With a modesty, which is not, perhaps, quite exempt from a tinge of irony, Lord Cromer disclaims for his -part superior degree of- knowledge which men who have not spent as many weeks, or perhaps days, in Egypt, as, he has spent years in administering that coun­try, readily affect. The movement which they feel sure they thoroughly understand is in some of its aspects obscure to- him It is the outcome, of the views-and of the sentiments of Orientals; and he remarks that he has "lived " too long in the East to dogmatize about the “ views of the inconsistent Oriental,'' for, whose inconsistency, he goes on to confess, he is not without sympathy. But he gives us some of the conclusions to which he has come, and they deserve our attentive study. In the first place, he remarks that the idea of Egyptian nationality, in the modern sense of the word, is wholly novel Egypt in her long history has passed through many vicissitudes, but all of them have been changes in her foreign mas­ters. Never-since the days of the Pharaohs has she been governed by lords of her own race The idea is not indigenous but exotic, and curiously enough, it has it* root in the benefi­cent system which it is seeking to undermine.

The "Times" in a subsequent leading article comments on -Lord Cromer's proposal with regard to the Capitulations, in the courts of which the journal says :— The Capitulations, which wore long necessary safeguards to the European inhabitants of Egypt, have become an obstacle to good government and to progress How formidable that obstacle is, even in such elementary matter of admin­istration as the maintenance of an effective police, Lord Cromer has proved in former reports. But it is not merely administration that they hamper; they are an almost in­superable barrier to any serious legislation that may affect tire European residents, who form *o very large and so important a part of tho population. Your by year, as this section of the population grows and its wealth and interesta in Egypt increase, the need of new legislation becomes more imperative. It would be a . boon to thorn and a boon to tho native*. But it cannot bo carried out By the Capitulations it requiree the assent of fifteen separate and independent Powers, and this provision, as Lord Cromer well say*, reduce* Egypt to a condition of legislative impotence.

He desires to free her from a restriction under which both Europeans and Egyptians sutler alike: He wants to abolish in port “legislation by diplomacy,” which in practice mean* the absence of much legislation imperatively and urgently required, and to substitute legislation, subject to certain limitations, by a local council, composed of Europeans, elected by Europeans, and able to legislate only with tho assout both of tho Egyptian and of the British Govern­ments. He repudiates any intention of “abolish­ing the Capitulations" He would preserve, he declares, all that is worth preserving in . them, while getting rid of those portions which are a useless drag upon the community.
Tho following tributes from the Radical organ art. especially noteworthy.

“ Tribune" As regards the genuinely national aspect of the modern move­ment, which cannot fail to oommand Lib ral sympathy in principle, it would be difficult to controvert lord Cromer’s view that govern­ment by a Ministry responsible to a native Egyptian Chamber would be in grave dan­ger, at preeont or within any measurable time, of meaning chaos, while complete finan­cial control would even more probably mean bankruptcy. Against "Egypt for the Egyp­tians” in the cruder sense Lord Cromer’s pro­nouncement is emphatic.

The Egyptians Lord Cromer has in view sro tho entire population of the tountry, native and European alike^f and he looks forward to a time when an International Legislative Council of all races and creeds represented in the Nile Valley aiiall be estab­lished in Egypt. He doea not pretend that this can be done to-morrow or the next day. Clearly the preeent Capitulations sys­tem, which hopelessly sets apart the Euro- pean Outlanders from the native Egyptians, is inconsistent with any such policy. But Lord Cromer has now given his own invaluable inspiration to an ideal which will substitute one common European interest for many, and a common Outlandernstiv'e interest for two interests that at present have no point of contact If his views can bo realized he will have set a crown indeed upon his great work for Egypt.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION
div.p: SYMPATHY IN PARLIAMENT.
MR. BALFOUR’S TRIBUTE.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday.

Sir Edward Grey's speech was received by both sides of the House with great, feeling, and much sympathy for the great statesman, who has been compelled to hand over his life's work through failing health, was shown. When the Secretary for Foreign Affairs concluded his speech the Hon A J Balfour rose. The regret, he said, which Sir Edward Grey has expressed would bo felt in an unqualified degree by every member of every party of the House of Commons and throughout the country. History alone could give an adequate estimate ot the work Lord Cromer has done. But we know enough and can survey with sufficient accuracy the magnitude of that work to feel how marvellous are the morally material labours which he has gone through and to admire the manner in which, under international and other difficulties, he had carried through the great task of his life.

Referring to Sir Eldon Gorst Mr. Balfour said that all who knew him recognised his great abilities, how unequalled was his knowledge of recent Egyptian developments, and, above all how anxious he was to carry out intact the policy so marvellously accomplished by Lord Cromer. We wish him every success.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PRESS COMMENTS
div.p: The European local Press of every nationa­lity is unanimous in its appreciation of Lord Cromer's work and in its regret at his resignation-

The policy of that part of the Nationalist Press, which is led by Mustapha Pasha Kamel, is to pretend that Lird Cromer's resignation is virtually a dismissal! "The Egyptian Standard'' and its Arabic and French confreres endeavour to show that the English Government has been obliged to dispense with Lord Cromer’s services as a consequence of Denishwai In case we may he thought by our readers to be exaggerating the point of view which these organs inculcate their ignorant readers with, we herewith re­produce the following comments from yester­day's issue ol "The Egpytian Standard

“Lord Cromer's departure from Egypt is an event that was expected by every one ever since the horrible and inexcusable Deushiwai incident/ Lord Cromer's policy wounded the Egyptians deeply and the British Government could no longer remain its equivocal situa­tion. A people can not be governed by being tortured and by the daily infliction of humilia­tions We have repeated more than once that our fight was against Lord Cromer's policy and not aga-n-t his personality We trust that the English Government will recognize the ne­cessity of changing the system with the man. We have now got satisfaction in a formal trans- forma'iou. The transformation must be ren­dered fundamental We want to be treated as men. not as slaves, as a nation, not as a herd.
There is in Egypt a national consciousness, the strength and importance of which must, not and cannot be underrated "

“The reason always given for the resignation of great men is a reason of health. But all those who know the nfi'airs ol Egypt ought to know with us that Lord Cromer was exceedingly anxious to remain in Egypt.
"His departure, wo repeat, is the logical consequence of his policy which had in Den ishwai its manifestation atnl its conclusion."

"A1 Moayad,'' which published a special edition yesterday, says The work of Lord Cromer in Egypt/ is bound up with all that has hnpponed during the 21 years he has passed in, this country as Diplomatic Agent slid the dilector of Egyptian policy. To say that nil he has performed has been eithor satis­factory or nll "ui.sniislact..ry would be hypocri­tical and untrue Generalspeakiug, LordCromor must bo placed am >ng the great statesmen ivh* havo retired, for be leaves behind him a history which will for long be a memorial to him. In so far as financial reform is concerned Lord Cromer has rendered the greatest service to Egypt and it is to bis able administration and valuable advioe that this country owes its exemption from the intolerable financial diffi­culties which it had furuierly to endure We c.ui say that Lord Cromer is one of tho most distinguished financiers of tho world, and the financial policy which ho 1ms adopted is ono calculated to ensure the advancement of tho Nile Valley Ho has advanced Egypt materially and had his knowledge of administration in judicial matters beenasgreat as his experien­ce in financo—which he inherited from the Barings, the fnmo s English financiers—our country would have been apd would be far happier than it is to-day The reason why Lord Cromer has not advanced this co ntry morally to the same extent as he has advanced it materially are, in the main, three Firstly his love of absolutism and of boosting, so that he lias' made the British officials and the Ministers of the Government as tools in his hands ; secondly his ei tire ignorance of the language of the country, which has ca- sed him to rely in all matters upon certain individuals who have monopolisedhisconfidence;aud thirdli,them st important of all, his attempt to guide Egypt towards conversion intoa British colony.

MEMORIAL TO LORD CROMER.
INTERNATIONAL SCHEME.

The idea of presenting a memorial to Lord Cromer as a mark of the universal esteem with which his work on behalf of Egypt is regarded by all classes of the population hits been taken up with considerable onthusiasm by the lead­ing members of the European colonies at Alexandria.

The/membcrs of the Greek commuhity of Alexandria havo already discussed the scheme among themselves and they are ready to unite with the other communities With a view to subscribing towards an international memorial. Otherwise they will subscribe among them­selves for-a memorial.

It is, of course, as yet too early to discuss what form the memorial should take. It might take two forms—one to be presented to Lord Cromer him-elf and the other to bean embodi­ment in a monumental form of tho osteem of all classes, whieji should recall to the mind of all future generations of the inhabitants of Egypt the memory of tho regenerator of their country, such as a fine statue or some other permanent monument.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MERCHANT SEAMEN’S HOME.
div.p: We have received from Mr. R. C. Craftcn, honorary secretary of the Alexandria Merchant Seamen’s Home, the annual report of tho Committee for the year ended 31»t of March lost, of which we publish tho following sum-

In submitting the annual report tho com­mittee have pleasure in recording tho con­tinued success which has attended tho work of the Home, und tho inoreaso in numbers awaiting themselves of the benefits afforded. That of late the demand on tho resources of the Homo should have so largely increased is not surprising, considering that during the six years which have passed since the opening of the present building, the trade of the port has augmented by over 50%, and there is reason to believe that in the near future it will bo doubled. To meet the demand os far as circumstances admit, has been the constant endeavour of the committee.

In the month, of November arrangements were made for taking in the crow (25 all told) of a steamer which had been sold, and was delivered over to her new owners at Alexandria, after discharging. Also in the months of August and September batches of men were received into the Home under some­what similar cireumstanea The admission of the above in addi-ion to men billeted ip usual course, or payinc for their lodging themselves, has taxed the sleeping accommodation at the Home The necessity for providing additional accommodation has oocupied the attention ot the committee, and in view of there being no unoccupied space at tho Home which oould be devoted to the purpoae,/they recommend as the only practical solution of tho difficulty, tho building of a room as an annex to the recreation room, on the vacant gronnd adjoin­ing to servo as a dormitory. For this extension the consent of the authorities would be necessary.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM
div.p: SELF GOVERNMENT DEMANDED.
KAMEL AND “THE TIMES.”
(Gazette Special Service. )
London, Saturday.

Mustapha Pasha Kamel lias written a letter on the usual lines to the ‘Times.” He insista that jthe Egyptians are ripe for self-govem-, went. The “Times” answers this communica­tion and alludes to the fact that the Nation­alist Press have rejoiced at Lord Cromer's re­signation. The ‘‘Times" remarks that if the Nationalists are capable of learning from ex­perience they should be referred to a remarkable testimony-published in tho “Cologne Gazette” . by a dispassionate German critic of Lord Cromer's work in Egypt After a striking review of Lord Cromer's record and the general situation in Egypt the Gorman newspaper ) comes to the conclusion that for the present the natives of Egypt must be kept under ' guardianship such as is now exoetcised by the : British over that country, for everything that British rale has bestowed in Egypt during the past quarter of a century is of a substantial, | enduring ami secure character.

div.head: CORPORATIONS OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: There is no need for the local shareholders : to be alarmed at the retirement of Crookslntnk Pasha and Maitro Carton do Wiart from the board of directors Tljcir resignations are tho inevitable prior Conditions to tbe solution of the Corporation’s great riddle. What and where is to be the sole oontrol I It must have been clear for sometime not only to tho board but to all connected with tho Corporation what decentralisation was an alwolute necessity, and this could best he effected by the present arrangement which puts tho very capable officials in charge of tho railway anil the oasis respectively in diroot communication with the London board. Shareholders may bo confident that theiriuterosts will be fully represented in Egypt. Resignations of member* of the staff must often be necessary in tho interests, of eoonomy as specialists replace one another and natives are trained to replace Europeans j Mr. Garseed, the late chemist in the Oases to the corporation, writes to us to state that he only severed his connection with the oompany owing to his having, completed the special investigations, which he was appointed to carry out.

Nestor Gianaclis oora- yising approximately 4,440 feddans situated in Abou-el-Matamirand Neguilah (Province of Behera) near Alexandria, we have been in-formed that the issue of this company will not take place until later Although the capital is' heavily applied for privately it is deemed advisable owing to some details still to be prepared to defer the public issue as above mentioned.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRADING AND FINANCE CO LTD
div.p: The subscription to this company will be open on Monday next and will close on the following day. The prospectus will be found on page seven of to-day's issue. The board of directors is composed of well known local men, who are well acquainted with the commercial and financial conditions prevailing in Egypt. The firm of Messrs Kyriacopoulo Brothers of Alexandria, who are the promoters of the Company, have a large business, and a numerous clientele, and the future prospects of the company appear to bo excellent. It is believed tliat the Capital will bo covered many times over. We are informed that a large number of persons wonted to take time by the forelock and subscribe to day.

div.head: ENGLAND AND JAPAN
div.p: PRINCE FUSHIMI’S VISIT.
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

It is announced that a Royal-review is to be held at Aldershot on the 9th of May in honour of Prince Fushimi ol Japan The King, the Queen, and all the members of the Royal family will attend Troops will be brought from London, Windsor, and other military centres.

div.head: THE GRANDMOULIN AFFAIR
div.p: The case of M. Grandmoulin came before the French consul yesterday morning. M. Grandmoulin was entirely acquitted of any negligence and it was decided that the death of the boy was accidental. It-will be remembered that M Grandmoulin went quail shooting, riding on his bicycle from Cairo to Embabeh, his rifle being fastened to his machine. When he got to Embabeh he left his bicycle at the side of the rood and went into a field where he shot several quails. A boy was carrying these for him to his bicycle, and while the act of fastening his rifle to his machine he heard the boy scream and turned round, his rifle accident­ly going of and shooting the boy. His brothers and the inhabitants of the village rushed up and would have beaten M. Grandmoulin had not the omdeh prevented it. M. Grandmoulin informed the French consul of his accident as soon as he got back to Cairo.

The two brothers of the dead boy were called as witnesses this morning, and said that M Grandmoulin deliberately shot their brother who asked him not to go into the wheat The chief gaffir was also examined but as he was not on the syyht at the time he could not give much useful evidence. The omdeh was also examined, particularly as to tko letter purporting to bo written by him, which was published in “Al Lewa" and other papers Tho consul asked him if he wrote it and ho denied writing it. Ho was tbon asked if ho had read it in "Al Lewa,” to which he replied that he' Tiad not, because he could neither read or write. It transpired that the latter was written by the tax collector.

div.head: NEW NILE STEAMER
div.p: The side-paddle steamer Egypt, the order for which was placed by Messrs. Thomas Cook and Son (Limited) with Messrs. John I. Thornycroft and Co. (Limited) in July, 1906, has been erected at tho Woolston Works, and is now being dismantled for shipment to Cairo, where she will bo ro-oreeted and completed for the Nile river service. She will be fitted with compound diagonal paddle engines and two loco-marino boilers. She has a largo accommoda­tion for passengers, and will be the largest steamer on the Nile Her dimensions, accom­modation, and construction ace as follows ;— Length—water-liny, 222ft.. over ill, 230ft.; beam—hull, 32ft., over sponsons, 51ft.; depth, 9ft. 6in.; draught, 3ft. 3in.; speed, 10J miles per hour; i.h p-, 300. Tho hull is of.steel, and tho vessel is provided with steam steering engine, steam windlass, and steam capstan. There are three passenger decks, with a wood awning nnd wheolhouse ovor the top (pro­menade) dock. On tho lower deck thore are eight single and eight doubto cabins; also cabins for stewardess, maids, and valets, nnd bath-rooms, store-rooms, bakery, ice-room, scul- licry, nnd pantry. The crew's quarters are forward. The dining and smoking rooms and cabins for engineer, doctor, manager, slid Wber are situated on the main deck, while on tho promenado dock aro four suites of cabitus de luxe (each comprising double berth cabin, sitting-room, anil bath) and- a large drawing-room. There is a, floe open deck. It is quite clear of pillars nigf other obstructions, and is suitable for dancing.

div.head: FIRE ON THE OSMANIEH
div.p: At 10.7 yesterday morning, « small- fire occurred on board the S.8. O-manieh now lying iu the Antcqal basin.

From enquiries, it appear* that one of the workmen dropped a plank which upset somo coal tar which became ignited. A great deal of smoko was seen coming from the ship, but fortunately tho fire drill on lioanl was carried out with commendable promptitude, aud the small fire confined to the stokehold, where, the tar having burnt itself out, tho fire hoses wore sufficient to prevent the fire extending to any other part of tho steamer where there was woodwork ; otherwise the consequences might have beqn very serious. As it is, no damage whatever has occured to the steamer.

Within a few miuutes alter the outbreak, the Ports and lights flie-float, in charge of Mr. J.E. Roberts, together with their launches and the hone gear were alongside the- steamer, hut fortunately the Khedivial Company did not need tlujirVrvices, although their prompt offer of assistance ia greatly appreciated.

div.p: ENROLMENT AS CADET.
(Gazette Speolal Service. )
London, Saturday.

There is to be an imposing display at Spit- head on May 2 when t&e Prince of Wales will accompany Prince Edward tq Osborne on tho Ocoosion of his entering the Naval college os a cadet The Coloniol premiers "will visit the port and the new home fleet will be anchored a Spithead with the Dreadnought and the whole of the Nore, Portsmouth, and Devonport divisions.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Pences George apd Coo rad of Bavaria arrived at Alexandria from Cairo today in order to embark on the ‘‘Oceana" for Europe.

M Klobukowsky, the French Diplomatic Agent, will leave Cairo to-morrow. He. will stay for 24 hours at Ismailia aod will embatk on Monday at Suez for Djibouti on the Mensa- gerica Maritime* S..S Adour. M. de Feloourt, third secretary at the French Agency, will accompany him on his mission to Abyssinia.
M. Barois will leave for Abyssinia in September.
Sir Horace Pinching's resignation has been accepted. Before leaving the service of the Government he will enjoy three and a half months leave of ahsence.
It is announced that Fehim Paoha has fled from Broussa and that he is on-his way to Egypt.

Mr. Ernest Stangen, one of the directors of the Hamburg American line, arrived this morning by the Company's Steamer Oceans, accompanied by Mrs. Stangen. Mr. Stangen intends to spend a few weeks in Egypt in order to take part in the general meetings of the several important companies he is connected with, and to inspect the recent extensive improvements that have been made in connection with the Nile tourist traffic.

The nomination of the Bov. T. H. Moles- worth, Viijar of St, John's, Leicester, to the Chaplaincy of All Saints,' Cairo, has received formal confirmation by tho community in Cairo and his appointment has been officially an­nounced in London.

div.head: A STEEL CANAL IN EGYPT
div.p: Messrs. T. Piggott and Co., of Birmingham have recently completed a remarkable canal in Egypt. It is to be used to convey water taken from the Nile at a point about 40 miles above the Assouan Dam, across the Eastern Desert to Kom-Ombo, where It will be used for irriga­tion. The peculiarity of the canal is that it is entirely constructed of steel. It is nearly a mile long by 6 metres wide, and is nude op of 17 sections, each about 100 metres long. These sections are coupled together with masonry basins, into which thoy can slide, to accom­modate tho expansion and contraction of the motal work, due to changes of temperature. The cross section of the canal is a semi-circle, surmounted by straight sides) metre high. It is mode of steel plates 6 millimetres thick, and itiflened by t section transverse ribs, and stayed from aide to side at the top with flat and angle straps. A longitudinal flange of 3 by 2} by | inch angle runs along the length of tho canal. The normal water level it at tho diameter of the cross section. The acqueduct is entirely above the ground level. It rests on a Sand foundation, and is banked up on eithqy «ide with earth.

Great difficulty was experienced in teaching the Arab workmen the use of pneumatic rivetters; in fact, the rivetters had eventually to be discarded in favour of hand work ; but tho natives learned how to caulk with pneumatic hammers It’ was found that each gang of rivetters could close about 300 rivets per day of ten hours, after a little training.

The temperature in tho shade was frequently 117 deg. F., and the wind often blew all the sand foundation from beneath the structure in one night. Nevertheless, the canal was com­pleted, by working day and night, in five months.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION
div.p: HOME PRESS OPINION. UNIVERSAL TRIBUTE OF ADMIRATION
London, April 12.

The subject of Lord Cromer's resignation fills the newspapers to the exclusion of every­thing else. No jarring note mars tho universal tribute of admiration paid to him and the fullest confidence is expressed in his suc­cessor.
The "Standard" says that no one owes a deeper debt to Lord Cromer than the Khe­dive.
The "Daily Telegraph' emphasises that his resignation is solely duo to tho state of his health.
The “Morning Post" says that the country will he grateful to the Government for its endorsement of Lord Cromer’s policy, the realisation of which is the greatest of national
The “Dally Chronicle" says that thanks to Lord Cromer the British policy in Egypt has remained outside the range of party differ
Tho "Daily News" says that this resignation ends the most honourable chapter of history of European Imperialism.
The “Tribune" sincerely- trusts that Sir Eldon Gorst possesses the imagination and the sympathy necessary to deal with the complicat­es! internal problem of Egypt
The “Daily Mail” says that Lord Cromer justifies tho confidence tho Unionists always reposed in Sir Edward Grey.
Hovse or Commons.—Sir Edward Grey's tribute to Lord Cromer was heartily cheered in all parts of the crowded house. M. Balfour warmly associated himself with it. (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRIAN ANARCHIST ARRESTED
div.p: Paris, April 12.
The police have arrested an Austrian anar­chist at the house of the Grand Duke Alexis at Paris. He has been released in consequence of the absence of proofs.(Havas)

div.head: SEIZURE OF ARMS AT NEWCASTLE
div.p: RUSSIAN REVOLUTIONARIES SUSPECTED.
London, April 12.

Three soparato seizures of rifles, pistols, and cartridge, 200,000 in all, have been made at Newcastle-on-Tyno. The owners have not been discovered but they are supposed to be Russian revolutionaries. (Reuter)

div.head: REACTION IN CHINA
div.p: NEW GOVERNOR OF MUKDEN.
London, April 12.
The "Time*" learns from Pelting that the reforming Minister Tangshaoyi has been ap­pointed Governor of the Mukden province, and consequently relinquishes all his post* in Peking.
In. an article commenting thereon the 'Time*" refer* to the ascendency of reaction in I'hinaand the denunciation of foreign influence by Progressives and Conservatives alike. (R.)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: AN ARMENIAN MONOPOLY
IN EGYPT.

To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette " Sir,—The following incident deserves notice as showing the admirably patriotic sentiments, which Boghos Pasha Nubar, chairmen of the board of the Alexandria Tramway Company, has in endeavouring to help his fellow country­men in Egypt A few days ago Mr. Joseph Bad- dour, a Syrian chemist and an American citizen, applied to the Alexandria headquarters of the Tramway Company for permission to sell tramway tickets by retail as is done at other establishments in this city. He was asked by the > Company whether he had tho honour of belonging to tho Armenian race. Mr Joseph Baddobr unfortunately does not enjoy the luxury of this racial distinction and ho replied in the negative Ho was then courteously informed thut his application could not be entertained as lie was not an Armenian ! I think such a system of encouraging Armenians in Egypt should be noticed and Boghos Pasha NuImit, who is the chairman gf tne Alexandria Tramway Company, should lie congratulated on his efforts to advance the interests of his fellow, countrymen in Egypt
I enclose my card and remain.—Yours etc., George S: O. Violara. Alexandria, 12th April.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANIES REPORTS
div.p: WARDEN ESTATE COMPANY.
The following is the report of the directors on the process of work carried out during the year ending 31st December 1906:—

The machinery for levelling the lands was, during the past year, much improved by the purchase of six of Mbura. J. Sc H. MoLaren’s large "Hassabiqhs," or levelling scoops, which have now been brought up to a gTeat state of perfection by this enterprising firm. The acqui sition of these machines has rendered it possible to reduce the company's lands to more continuous and uniform slopes across the land from the low level canal that runs through the estate to the railway on one side or the desert on the other, thus making the final selling value of the land greater and enabling the red flood water to deposit its silt more uniformly oter tho land, consequently, though tho steam engines and tackle now do fully double the wuTk they were doing before we acquired these new "Hassa- biehs,” oar geueral manager has decided, rather than accelerate the progress of the levelling as far as area is concerned, to do the work in a more thorough manner than it was possible to do it before. In all about 850 feddans were levelled during the year.
FLOOD.
The flood of 1906 was a fair average one and the deposit of silt on the levelled lands was very satisfactory.
WATER SUPPLY.

The sinking of the tube wells was pushed forward with considerable energy ; contracts have been entered into for the sinking of all tho wells that will lie necessary to put the whole of the company's lands under ‘Sefi" irrigation. The-e wells will be completed during tlie course of tins current year. /

The underground supply of water is, for all practical purposes,-unlimited and the flow into the tube well so free that the pumps give a full delivery working day and night. This under­ground water supply is one of our most valu-able asset for, as was pointed out in our last annual report, we have '"Sefi" water for the whole estate without the usual interruptions of summer rotations.
TREE PLANTING.

The area under trees planted during the past year was brought up to 529 feddans to which must bo added 164 feddans of syssel plants bringing up the total area to 693 feddans The balance, to complete the 1,1)00 feddans. which, by the terms of our agreement with the Government have to bo planted, will lie completed during the current year. Both the trees and tho syssel plants are doing extremely well and show a vigorous and healthy growth.
CULTIVATION.

Hitherto our cultivation has been restricted to the growing of forage crops for the use of the compeuy’s cattle, the reason being that our " Sefi " water supply was not completed, and further the necessity of flooding the land and keeping the water on it for a long period so that it should deposit all its silt. The Khatatbah Estate is now sufficiently coima- t izod to enable ‘ us to grow sefi crops and the water installation is also rapidly approaching completion. We have rented a portion of this estate amounting to about 100 feddans at L.E. 5 per feddan per annum an 1 are arran­ging to cultivate a large area with “ foul suudani ” (ground nuts) which crop has been proved to Succeed very well on that land, We would draw the shareholders attention to Mr. Lang Anderson’s report which is printed at the end this report and which we are sure will be found very interesting.
CAPITAL

The issue of 10,000 shares sanctioned a1 tho annual general meeting was allataken up, but us most of the monoy was not requirec , at the time the director* only called up £2.10.( por share. Our general manager has beet requested to make a careful estimate of wha further capital will be required to complete tin reclamation of the whole of our concession am as practically everything except the levolliiij of some five thousand feddans of land ha* no* been completed, or is in an advanced stage towards completion, this estimate can bo relies upon as lieing accurate. Ho calculate*, a* wil Imi seen from Ills report attached hereto, tliat ■ total expenditure of I*E. 146,685 is require! as-from tlio 31st decembor 11906 to compleU all reclamation. Our available resources, ai will also lie seen by the account* publishes with this report, were on the same dato :
Cash in bank and on hand L.E. 18.311.66i Calls to be made 29.250 00(

» We therefore will require a further sum Ol iMOOiOOO to complete tbe reclamation of thi whole estate but as available fund* are ampii ' to carry on the' work for the preaent no fresl issue is contemplated in the immediate future thoughyour directorsaregii ingcareful consider atlon aa to the heat memf* of raising further

capital when a necessity for the same shall arise. In conclusion your directors have no hesitation in saying that they are convinced of the unqualified success of your enterprise feeling confident that in thg pjef future Jbey will be in i {xftitlou tb distribute’ substantial dividends from revenue derived from constantly increasing rentals of your lands, while at the same time the oapital vabie of your property will be improving from year to year.
Chairman,
J. W. WILLIAMSON.

There will be no changes in the Royal'Artil lory force in Egypt in the coming relief.season, the present unit* remaining as thoy are now stationed.

The launch of the now battleship Inflexible, which was to have takon place on Saturday next at the yard of Messrs John Brown & Co., has been delayed owing tq the discovery of some defects in’ the castings of the stern
It is understood that when the 1st King's Dragoon Guards go to India in tho coming relief season, they will be stationed el Umballa in the Punjab.
Between now and this time next year, the R iyal Engineers are to be reduced by some 900 men in' accordanco with Mr. Haldane's fatuous policy. Electricians, however, ore to bo retained in all case*.

The new appointment of Commander-in- Chief of tho troops jin the Mediterranean is looked upon as a very good substitute for the abolished appointment of Commandor-in-Chief of tho Army, and of course, not a few see in it a "job,” or profess that they do.

Lieutenant L 8/C. Rose, 3rd Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, who has ju*t severed his connection with tho regiment, got his communion in February, 1900, and saw a good deal of fighting in Natal and the Trans­vaal, 190002, whilst employed with the Transport (Queen’s medal with three clasps, King's medal with two claspa); and ho was employed with the Intelligence Department in the operation against the Mad Mullah of 8o- maliiand, 1902-04.(medal with Clasp),

div.head: Walker & Meimarachi, Limited
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that in conformity with a Requisition by Egyptian Shareholders an Extraordinary Ueneral Meeting of the above named Company will be held at the Company's Office, 65, London Wall, London, E.C., on Monday the 29th April 1907 at 3 p m., for the purpose of altering the Com­pany's Articles of Association with a viow to transferring the Directorate and the administra­tion of the Company's affairs from London to Cairo.

Shareholders wishing to be represented at this Meeting must deposit their Shares in the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited, Cairo or Alex­andria at latest on or before Tuesday the 16th instant, or at the Company Office in London at latest on or before Thursday the 25th instant.
Forms of Proxy can be obtained at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd. in Cairo or Alex­andria or at the Chambers of Maitre L Carton de Wiart, Standard Building, Sharia Kasr El Nil, Cairo.
By Order of the Board
O. W. BEXSET
Secy, for Egypt

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: This Company has been formed for the purposes specified in the Memorandum ol Association, and in particular :— qS-

list.item: To effect the purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the local and continental bourse*, and tho London Stock Exchange for their own account and for the account of third porsons.
To undertake the purchase and Vile of cotton, cotton seed and other produce on the local and continental bourses and in England for their o*h account and for the account of third persons.

To undertake evory kind of Exchange, Bourse, financial and commercial operations, including advances on' Stock Exchange securities and upon cotton and cotton seed and othei merchandise, carrying over securities, arbitrations, discount and other commission business

div.p: The arrangements made for the formation of the Company are embodied in two agreements, the Erst dated the 20th March, 1907, mado between Messrs. Kyriacopoulo Frtres .t Cie. Jean Coury, Joan Apostolidi, Emino Boy Yehia, Loiso . N. Loiso, Joseph P. Hodeir, Antoine Apostolidi and Jean Panajotou and the second dated the 20th March, 1907, made between Messrs. Eustache Kyriacopoulo and .Ulysse Kyriacopoulo, and Mr. Khalifa El Dik, the partners and sleeping partner respectively in the firm of Kyriacopoulo Frtres A Cie, of the one part, and Mr. Antoine Apoatolidi as trustee for this Company, of tho other part.

The subscribers to the first mentioned agreement have an reed to take firm 33,000 Ordinary Shares in the Company in tho proportions given below and will have allotted to them 1,700 of the Deferred 8 ha res in the proportions also given below, both Ordinary and Deferred Shares being subscribed for wholly iu cash.
Or 'inary Shares taken. Ann- Deferred Shares
Jean Coury 2,000 100
Jean Apostolidi 8,000 . 100
Emine Bey Yehia 2,000 100
Loiao N. Loiso 5,000 100
Antoine Apostolidi 5,000 50
Jean Panajotou 6,000 50
Joseph P. Hodeir 2,000 100
Kyriacopoulo Fibres A- Cie. 7,000 1100

The Company will have the advantage of the services of Messrs. Kyriacopoulo Frtres A Cie., one of the oldest firms of Brokers in Egypt, whose wide experience and well known rapacities cannot fail to secure tho success of the'Company.

By vitue of the two agreements above, Messrs. Kyriacopoulo Frtres A Cie. undertake to work exclusively for account of the Company, and to pas* over to the Company the whole of their clientele and current business as from the ls.t May, 1907. The Company on their part undertake to transact all their business through Kyriacopoulo Frtres A Cie., and only work with or through them. In case this Company shall decide to do business in its own name as brokers Messrs. Kyriacopoulo will act only in their respective capacities of Managing Director and General Manager. In consideration of these engagements the remaining 2,600 Deferred Shares of the Company will be allotted to Kyriacopoulo Frtres & Cie. or tjieir nominees, to be paid for wholly in cash.
,___ . Mr. Eustache Kyriacopoulo under the above agreement is appointed Managing Director

of the Company on a salary of £1,200 a year plus 3 1/2% on the nett profits before they are dealt with as mentioned below. Mr. Ulysse Kyriacopoulo is appointed General Manager of the Company on the same salary and commission Both these agreements are for ten years.

The Directors are interested in the promotion of the Company to the extent set out __ above and as shown in the agreements above referred to, which contains all the arrangements ’ made in contemplation of the formation of the Company.

The provisions of the Memorandum and Articles of Association "with regard to the posi­tion of the share holders, the division of profits,- tho creation of a Reserve Fund, and the rerau neration of the Directors, are aa follows :—

From and out of the profits which ip respect of each year shall, after deduction of any share attributed to tho Managing Director or Manager of the Company, be available for dividends, a sum equal to 10% of such profits shall be carried to a special Reserve Fund a until such Reserve Fund amounts to a sum equal to one-fourth of the capital for the time being of the Company ; tho balance of such profits shall bo dealt with aa follows :—

The holders of the Ordinary shares will takes fixed preferential Dividend not exceed­ing the rate of 6% p.a. on tho Capital for the time being paid up or credited as being paid up thereon respectively, such Dividend to be paid as regard! each year out of tho profits of such yearabd to be non-cumulative.

The balance remaining of the surplus profits after providing for the above-mentioned Reserve Fund, and Preferential Dividend shall be divided as to 60% among the holders * of the Ordinary Shares fatcably and in proportion to the number of Ordinary Shares held by them respectively, add as to 40% amojig the holders of the Deferred Shares ratoably and in proportion to th« number of shares held by them respectively.
The holder, of the Ordinary Shares are entitle.! to priority a*1 to return of capital and payment of dividends, whether declared or not, up to the commencement of the winding up.

As remunegriion for their sen-ires the Direct-ire, other than the Managing Director, will be paid at the rate of £100 a year for each ordinary Director, and at the rate of £150 a year for the Chaimiau.
In addition to the aforesaid remuneration, each Director shall also receive such further sum (if any) as the Company in Genmal Meeting may from time to time determine.
. Any Director may be employed by or hold any office of profit under the

Company, except that of Auditor of the Company, and may act either personally or aa a member of the firm for, or render any professional service to the Com­pany, and may receive remuneration from the Company for so doing to addition to an^ remuneration payable to him as a Director. Jf any Director, being wTl

I'ng, we shall be railed upon to perform extra services or to make any apecial exerfiona in going or reaiding abroad, or in negotiating or carrying Into effect any contract or arrangement by' the Company or otherwise for any of the par- poeee of the Company, or to act ai truitee for the Company or its debenture holders, and- shall do ao, the Company may remunerate auch Director either by a fixed aum or-percentage of profile, or otherwiae, aa may bo determined by tbo Directors, and anch remuneration may be either in addition to. or in aubatitution for, hia-remuneration above provided. If any Director shall be appointed to represent the Company aa a Director of any subsidiary or other company in which tho Company shall bo interested, he shall, unless otherwise agreed, be entitled to retain the remuneration attaching to such Directorship for his own use.
Tho qualification of a Director is the holding of BOO Ordinary Shares. The Company in general meeting may increase or reduce the number of Directors and may alter the qualification.
No promotion money will be paid.
The Capital of the Company can be increased under tho Articles of Associa­tion up to £600,000 by the Board of Directors*. I

The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of tho Company down to and including allotment, including registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses, the cost of advertising and issuing this prospectus, but excluding stamp duty on share warrants, will be paid'by the Company, and are estimated at £2 000. / Application for shares should be. made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company’s bankers; the Banque d'Athines, Alexandria, Cairo and Loudon. U no allotment is made, tho appli- cation money will bo returnod in full, and where the number of shares allotted i* leas than the number applied for, tho surplus will" be credited in reduction' of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant
Tho Directors reserve to themselves discretion in the allotment of shares. Failure to pay an instalment on shares when due will render previous- payments liable to be forfeited. 1
The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at 40 % of tho shares offered.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association, which forms part of this Prospectus, is endorsed hereon.

The above-mentioned contracts or copies of-"those documents, together with tho print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association, may be inspected at the offices of Messrs. Kyriacopoulo Frtres & Cie., Alexandria, and at tb<* offices of the legal advisers to the Company at Alexandria.
Copies of this prospectus and application forms can be obtained at tho same offices and at tho offices of the Bankers of the Company at Alexandria.
299874-1 • bated 4th April 1907.

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
